item.title: Talks taking place over removal of Gavin from ballot

item.title: Parolin on October 7, Gaza: Human beings are not collateral damage
item.description:
The Holy See Secretary of State speaks to Vatican Media on the second anniversary of Hamas's “inhuman” attack on Israel, which unleashed the destruction of the Gaza Strip. He says that what is happening in Gaza is “inhuman”, and that he's struck by the turnout at peace marches. He adds that antisemitism is a cancer that must be eradicated.

item.title: Darfur: ICC convicts Janjaweed leader of war crimes and crimes against humanity
item.description: Two decades after the scorched-earth campaign that left hundreds of thousands dead in Sudan’s Darfur, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has delivered its first conviction linked to the conflict, finding Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman “Ali Kushayb”, guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.
item.source:markdown: Two decades after the scorched-earth campaign that left hundreds of thousands dead in Sudan’s Darfur, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has delivered its first conviction linked to the conflict, finding Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman “Ali Kushayb”, guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

item.title: Where despair meets mercy: Church’s mission in Colombian slum
item.description:
In the south of Bogotá, in what was once a middle-class Colombian neighborhood, lies the “Barrio San Bernardo.” Today, this area bears the marks of marginalization and despair, but within it, seeds of hope are being planted by a young parish priest, Fr. Juan Felipe Quevedo.

item.title: Bishops dedicate Kenya to Mary, Mother of God, during National Prayer Day

item.title: Budget 2026: €10 rise in pension, welfare rates expected
item.description: A €10 increase in the State pension and Social Protection rates is expected in tomorrow's Budget. The Budget will also see mortgage interest relief, which has benefitted more than 60,000 householders, extended for another year before being gradually phased out in 2027.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV encourages rekindling awareness of our missionary vocation
item.description:
At the Mass for the Jubilee of the Missions and of Migrants, Pope Leo encourages us to rekindle awareness of our missionary vocation that springs from a desire to “bring the joy and consolation of the Gospel to everyone,” remembering those in difficulty, and in particular “our migrant brothers and sisters” forced to leave their homelands.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.description: The Arctic’s cold waters have – for the most part – prevented invasive species from migrating north. item.title: In February 2026 relics of St. Francis of Assisi to be on public display
item.description:
The announcement of the public display for veneration comes from the Sacro Convento in Assisi on the day the Church and the world celebrate the feast of the Saint Francis of Assisi. Thanks to the approval of Pope Leo XIV, the body of the Saint, on the occasion of the 800th anniversary of his death, will be moved from his tomb, located in the crypt of the Franciscan basilica, and placed at the foot of the papal altar in the lower church.

Read all

item.title: Russian strikes on Ukraine trains kill one, injure 30
item.description: Two Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials have said, with Ukraine's foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.
item.source:markdown: Two Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials have said, with Ukraine's foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.

Two Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials said on Saturday, with Ukraine's foreign affairs minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.

item.title: In 4 months, Canadian Jeremy Hansen will blast off to the moon — where he'll also be a human guinea pig
item.description: If all goes to plan, next February could see the return of humans to the moon. Four people — NASA astronauts Victor Glover, Reid Wiseman, Christina Koch and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen — will see it as no one has before. And they will also be collecting valuable health data on themselves.
item.source:markdown:
![A man in a blue astronaut jumpsuit stands with his arms crossed in front of the blue NASA logo.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7649483.1759426815!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/jeremy-hansen-jsc.jpg)
If all goes to plan, next February could see the return of humans to the moon. Four people — NASA astronauts Victor Glover, Reid Wiseman, Christina Koch and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen — will see it as no one has before. And they will also be collecting valuable health data on themselves.

item.title: There could be 'mutual interest' in Canada building its submarines, says German armament secretary
item.description: The notion of Canada becoming a submarine-building nation is not that far-fetched, Germany’s armaments state secretary says. Jens Plötner said ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems — one of two bidders in the submarine program — has done it in other countries and all Canada has to do is ask.
item.source:markdown:
![Four people wear suits and hardhats. One of the holds a model submarine.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7650905.1759520915!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/carney-germany-20250826.jpg)
The notion of Canada becoming a submarine-building nation is not that far-fetched, Germany’s armaments state secretary says. Jens Plötner said ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems — one of two bidders in the submarine program — has done it in other countries and all Canada has to do is ask.

item.title: Guinea-Bissau: Catholics called upon to initiate dialogue and fraternity
item.description:
The Diocese of Bafatá in Guinea-Bissau has celebrated its 25th anniversary with a strong appeal for national fraternity and dialogue. Bishop Victor Luis Quematcha made the call in his Pastoral Letter to the Diocese. Addressed first to Catholics, the Bishop says that the Catholic community should be the first to take steps in dialogue and fraternity, with the view to building a united and inclusive society.

Read all

item.title: DR Congo: UN envoy urges people eager for peace in the east ‘not to lose hope’
item.description: For people in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) exhausted by years of conflict, the United Nations envoy for the country said she understands their impatience but urges them “not to lose hope” as the Congolese government, the UN and the international community are “determined” to bring peace to the volatile region.

item.description: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Friday that millions in Somalia are at risk of worsening hunger and malnutrition as critical funding shortfalls force the agency to cut back on life-saving emergency food assistance.

item.description:

item.title: Wild dogs, disease threaten displaced Gaza families living in landfill
item.description: In Al-Zawaida, in the central Gaza Strip, some families driven out of their homes by the Israel-Hamas war have set up shelter in a landfill. 'I try to protect my kids. I don’t sleep so the dogs don’t come in on us,' Omar Al-Far, 41, says. 'There’s poison and the smell of dead animals.'

item.title: How Syria's first elections since autocrat Assad's ouster could unfold
item.description: Syria is set to hold parliamentary elections on Sunday for the first time since the fall of the country’s longtime autocratic leader Bashar al-Assad, who was unseated in a rebel offensive in December.

Syria is set to hold parliamentary elections on Sunday for the first time since the fall of the country’s longtime autocratic leader Bashar al-Assad, who was unseated in a rebel offensive in December.

item.title: Philippines earthquake: UN pledges support as Cebu death toll rises to 72
item.description: Hospitals are overwhelmed and families are sheltering in the open after a deadly 6.9 magnitude earthquake tore through northern Cebu in the Philippines, killing at least 70 people and displacing more than 20,000, according to local authorities and humanitarians on the ground.

item.title: The Syria prison survivor seeking justice for the missing
item.description: When the gates of Syria’s notorious Sednaya prison opened soon after the fall of the Assad regime last December, graffiti scrawled on the walls offered a frightening glimpse into what was widely known as the “human slaughterhouse”. “First day, severe beating,” one prisoner wrote.

item.title: Increasing violence and funding cuts imperil millions across Haiti

item.title: Sudan: UN rights chief calls for urgent action to protect civilians in El Fasher
item.description: UN human rights chief Volker Türk on Thursday warned that civilians in Sudan’s El Fasher face the imminent risk of large-scale atrocities, as fighting intensifies around the regional capital of North Darfur, besieged for more than 500 days by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia.
item.source:markdown: UN human rights chief Volker Türk on Thursday warned that civilians in Sudan’s El Fasher face the imminent risk of large-scale atrocities, as fighting intensifies around the regional capital of North Darfur, besieged for more than 500 days by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia.

item.title: Gaza health system overwhelmed as WHO reports 42,000 people have life-changing injuries
item.description: Nearly 42,000 people in Gaza are living with life-changing injuries from the ongoing conflict – including more than 10,000 children – as the health system collapses under relentless strain, the World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Thursday.
item.source:markdown: Nearly 42,000 people in Gaza are living with life-changing injuries from the ongoing conflict – including more than 10,000 children – as the health system collapses under relentless strain, the World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Thursday.

item.title: Anti-government youth protests in Morocco turn deadly
item.description: Two people were killed and others injured when security forces in Morocco opened fire on protesters who where attempting to steal their weapons, local authorities said. The protests, which began Saturday with demands for better education and healthcare, have been organized online by a loosely formed youth group called GenZ 212.
item.source:markdown:
![Anti-government youth protests in Morocco turn deadly ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/451e0fda-247d-474f-b8ef-0e25a2ca7556,1759407525331/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Two people were killed and others injured when security forces in Morocco opened fire on protesters who where attempting to steal their weapons, local authorities said. The protests, which began Saturday with demands for better education and healthcare, have been organized online by a loosely formed youth group called GenZ 212.

item.title: First Nation calls deteriorating state of Whitehorse dam fish ladder 'extremely concerning'
item.description: According to documents posted on the Yukon Water Board registry, the timbers in a portion of the roughly 366-metre fish ladder are deformed and deteriorating. First identified by staff on Sept. 12, the company has been focused on obtaining an emergency amendment to its new water licence, so it can make needed repairs.
item.source:markdown:
![A very long aparatus, not much wider than an actual ladder, descends a considerable distance above tall shrubs toward the water. It is filled with water and has what appear to be rungs across it. In fact, they are the dividers between tiny pools of slightly different heights that the fish jump through to climb to the top of the dam. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7617541.1759183087!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/fish-ladder.jpg)
According to documents posted on the Yukon Water Board registry, the timbers in a portion of the roughly 366-metre fish ladder are deformed and deteriorating. First identified by staff on Sept. 12, the company has been focused on obtaining an emergency amendment to its new water licence, so it can make needed repairs.

item.title: Strong earthquake kills at least 69 in central Philippines, damages homes and buildings

item.title: Rohingya plight in Myanmar, a ‘test for humanity’
item.description: “Houses burned. Neighbours killed. Hope vanishing.” With those stark words, General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock opened a high-level UN conference on Tuesday, as alarm rises over the impact of Myanmar’s deepening crisis which threatens to destabilise the wider region.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors authorise new Gang Suppression Force for Haiti
item.description: The UN Security Council has backed a resolution authorising the transition of the Kenyan-led support mission for Haiti into a new Gang Suppression Force, in close cooperation with Haitian authorities. US Ambassador Michael Waltz said it offered new hope for the country's future as “a key first step” to address the humanitarian and security crisis there. Follow the meeting live below; UN News app users need to click here for coverage.

item.description: Doctors in Gaza are warning of a surge in respiratory illnesses as families – cut off from basic supplies – burn plastic and cardboard to cook and keep warm. They say the outbreak will worsen unless life-saving medicines, fuel and food are allowed into the devastated territory.

item.title: Mother Cabrini Institute Founder: 'We know immigrants and trust them with our lives'
item.description:
In an interview with Vatican News, Michele Pistone, law professor at Villanova University's Charles Widger School of Law, and founding faculty director of Villanova's just-launched Mother Cabrini Institute on Immigration, explains concrete efforts, also to help rediscover the humanity of immigrants whom we so often welcome into the most intimate areas of our lives, like caring for our children and elders.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In an interview with Vatican News, Michele Pistone, law professor at Villanova University's Charles Widger School of Law, and founding faculty director of Villanova's just-launched Mother Cabrini Institute on Immigration, explains concrete efforts, also to help rediscover the humanity of immigrants whom we so often welcome into the most intimate areas of our lives, like caring for our children and elders.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-09/mother-cabrini-institute-immigration-interview-michele-pistone.html)

item.title: 46% of Irish population now have health insurance - HIA
item.description: The number of people with private health insurance rose slightly between April and June, despite a significant spike in the cost of premiums.

item.title: UN appeals to Taliban to restore internet, telecommunications access across Afghanistan
item.description: The United Nations mission in Afghanistan urged the Taliban on Tuesday to restore internet and telecommunications access across the country, saying the blackout imposed by the government in Kabul has left the country almost entirely cut off from the outside world.
item.source:markdown:

The United Nations mission in Afghanistan urged the Taliban on Tuesday to restore internet and telecommunications access across the country, saying the blackout imposed by the government in Kabul has left the country almost entirely cut off from the outside world.

item.title: Key points from US peace proposal for Gaza
item.description: The White House has released a 20-point peace proposal that calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, an exchange of hostages held by Hamas for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel, a staged Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, and Hamas disarmament.
item.source:markdown: The White House has released a 20-point peace proposal that calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, an exchange of hostages held by Hamas for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel, a staged Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, and Hamas disarmament.

item.title: Inquiry into CHI care will be 'effective', says Taoiseach
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said the Government will ensure that a promised inquiry into the care of spina bifida and scoliosis patients at Children's Health Ireland (CHI) is "effective" as well as being "transparent and public".

item.description: ɬagət̓ hiyt t̓oxʷʊm Herring to Huckleberries by ošil (Betty Wilson) is written in both English and ʔayʔajuθəm, helping to teach the next generation of Tla'amin their traditional language.

item.title: Wolf attack in Greece prompts calls for culling rights
item.description: Hunters and farmers in Greece are demanding the right to cull wolves after one attacked a child on a beach this month, warning that the protected species is multiplying in the wild.
item.source:markdown: Hunters and farmers in Greece are demanding the right to cull wolves after one attacked a child on a beach this month, warning that the protected species is multiplying in the wild.

item.title: Kent Monkman's Montreal exhibition challenges colonial gaze with Indigenous narratives
item.description: The exhibit, entitled History is Painted by the Victors, is on display at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts from Sept. 30 until March 8. In his grandiose works, the Cree artist paints colonial scenes that put Indigenous people at the forefront, using a neoclassical style.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman stands in front of large painting by Kent Monkman at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/106cbc95-e759-4879-800d-fdfe6ffc294f,1758734350225/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Trump: Hamas has three or four days to respond to deal
item.description: US President Donald Trump has said he is giving Hamas "three or four days" to respond to his Gaza ceasefire plan, under which the group must fully disarm and be excluded from future roles in government.

item.title: Iranian director Jafar Panahi defies censors again
item.description: The Iranian director Jafar Panahi, whose latest film won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in May, has told AFP he will continue to defy his country's censors and ignore the risk of returning to prison.

item.title: 'We haven't lost our language': How Opaskwayak Cree Nation's immersive program shapes new speakers
item.description: The melody of kids singing O Canada in Cree rings through Joe A. Ross School’s intercom speakers and echoes through the building. It’s how classes at the Opaskwayak Cree Nation school start each morning, but their use of Cree doesn’t end there.

item.description: The British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has warned his party that the UK stands at a fork in the road between decency and division.

item.title: Nicole Kidman and Keith Urban have reportedly separated

item.title: Comedians performing at Saudi Arabia comedy festival called out for 'whitewashing' country's regime
item.description: Some of the world's biggest comedians, including Dave Chappelle, Louis C.K., Pete Davidson and Kevin Hart, are performing at the Riyadh Comedy Festival — but not everyone is laughing. Some other comics and the non-profit group Human Rights Watch, have criticized those performing, noting the country's record of human rights abuses.
item.source:markdown:
![three men in suits pictured on red carpets in this composite image](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7646993.1759190923!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/chapelle-davidson-ck-composite.jpg)

item.title: How a landmark 1983 adoption case left a First Nations girl trying to 'not be brown anymore'
item.description: Leticia Racine was just seven when the Supreme Court ruled that her foster parents should be allowed to adopt her. She has spent over 40 years untangling that decision and understanding its impact on other Indigenous kids in Canada.
item.source:markdown:
![Leticia stands next to Linda and leans her head against Linda who's smiling.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645291.1759430959!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpeg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/leticia-racine-and-linda-daniels.jpeg)
Leticia Racine was just seven when the Supreme Court ruled that her foster parents should be allowed to adopt her. She has spent over 40 years untangling that decision and understanding its impact on other Indigenous kids in Canada.

item.title: 'Never give up hope': Percy Onabigon is home after First Nation family spent decades repatriating his remains
item.description: With the repatriation of his remains, Percy Onabigon has finally returned to Long Lake #58 First Nation, 79 years after he was taken from the northern community and put into a residential school in southwestern Ontario. Here's what his reburial means to his family and community leaders, and why they're calling for more support to help others repatriate lost loved ones.
item.source:markdown:
![A person wearing a black and orange ribbon skirt is seen placing her hand on a casket,](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645736.1759010228!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/claire-onabigon.jpg)
With the repatriation of his remains, Percy Onabigon has finally returned to Long Lake #58 First Nation, 79 years after he was taken from the northern community and put into a residential school in southwestern Ontario. Here's what his reburial means to his family and community leaders, and why they're calling for more support to help others repatriate lost loved ones.

item.title: YouTube to pay $22m in settlement with Trump

item.title: US to impose 100% tariff on movies made outside the US
item.description: President Donald Trump said today he would impose a 100% tariff on all films produced overseas that are then sent into the US, repeating a threat made in May that would upend Hollywood's global business model.

item.title: Texas police link deceased serial killer to 1991 yogurt shop killings of 4 teen girls
item.description: Police in Texas on Monday outlined how they linked a man connected to homicides in other states to the 1991 unsolved killings of four teenage girls at an Austin yogurt shop, saying DNA evidence led to a "significant breakthrough" in the brutal crime that has haunted the state's capital and stumped investigators for decades.

item.title: After mass exodus, limbo: Rohingya refugees test international resolve
item.description: More than eight years after over 750,000 Rohingya Muslims fled Myanmar for sprawling camps in Bangladesh, the crisis remains unresolved. On Tuesday, world leaders, UN officials and civil society groups will convene in New York for a high-level summit to confront not just the humanitarian emergency, but the geopolitical deadlock that perpetuates it.
item.source:markdown: More than eight years after over 750,000 Rohingya Muslims fled Myanmar for sprawling camps in Bangladesh, the crisis remains unresolved. On Tuesday, world leaders, UN officials and civil society groups will convene in New York for a high-level summit to confront not just the humanitarian emergency, but the geopolitical deadlock that perpetuates it.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: ‘Devastation’ in Gaza and beyond reinforces need to end Palestine occupation
item.description: The UN Security Council is meeting to discuss the Middle East crisis and protection of civilians in conflict, as speculation grows of a potential deal to end the war in Gaza with US President Donald Trump and Israeli premier Benjamin Netanyahu meeting in the White House for talks on Monday. Follow live coverage from the council chamber in New York below; UN News app users can go here.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council is meeting to discuss the Middle East crisis and protection of civilians in conflict, as speculation grows of a potential deal to end the war in Gaza with US President Donald Trump and Israeli premier Benjamin Netanyahu meeting in the White House for talks on Monday. Follow live coverage from the council chamber in New York below; UN News app users can go here.

item.title: Ukraine suffers renewed, massive Russian airstrikes overnight
item.description: In Ukraine, people across the country have been dealing with the aftermath of a massive Russian bombing raid that lasted into the early hours of Monday, reportedly killing four, including a teenage girl.
item.source:markdown: In Ukraine, people across the country have been dealing with the aftermath of a massive Russian bombing raid that lasted into the early hours of Monday, reportedly killing four, including a teenage girl.

item.title: ‘House of diplomacy and dialogue’: UN wraps up high-level week with calls for peace, climate action and reform
item.description: The United Nations remains “the house of diplomacy and dialogue” in a divided world, General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock said as she closed the 80th session’s general debate, urging nations to convert the week’s momentum into concrete action on peace, climate change and institutional reform.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations remains “the house of diplomacy and dialogue” in a divided world, General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock said as she closed the 80th session’s general debate, urging nations to convert the week’s momentum into concrete action on peace, climate change and institutional reform.

item.title: Candidates seek to avoid major fumbles in first debate
item.description: Tonight marks a significant milestone in the presidential election with the first major candidate debate.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV urges European institutions to promote a 'healthy secularism'
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV receives the Working Group on Intercultural and Interreligious Dialogue, an initiative of the European Parliament, insisting that 'European institutions need people who know how to live a healthy secularism,' and reaffirming that 'being men and women of dialogue means remaining deeply rooted in the Gospel and in the values that flow from it.'

Read all

item.title: French court opens new trial on AF447 crash 16 years ago
item.description: Airbus and Air France pleaded not guilty to manslaughter at the start of a new trial over France's worst air disaster, 16 years after a Paris-bound jet crashed into the Atlantic, killing all passengers and crew, including three young Irish women.

item.title: Europe, Russian confrontation a 'new type of war' - Tusk
item.description: The Prime Minister of Poland Donald Tusk has said that the current confrontation between Europe and Russia is a "new type of war".

item.title: Threats to democracy 'more common, more acute' - McGrath
item.description: European Commissioner for Democracy, Justice and the Rule-of-Law Michael McGrath, has said that threats to democracy have become "more common, more acute and more complex".

item.title: Man in his 30s arrested over deaths in Tallanstown
item.description: Follow live updates after three people are found dead in what gardaí believe is murder at a house in Tallanstown in rural Louth.

item.title: Bodies of husband, wife and son removed from Louth home
item.description: Follow live updates as gardaí investigate what they believe is the murder of three people at a house in the Drumgowna area of Co Louth.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV receives the President of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV receives the President of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, Mr Umaro Sissoco Embaló, in the Vatican on Monday, and during their discussions, the contribution of the Catholic Church to the country's common good was noted.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Tourist numbers rise by 1.2% in August - CSO
item.description: Tourist numbers in August, a key month for the hospitality industry, were up 1.2% compared to last year.

item.title: Three family members killed in Co Louth named locally
item.description: The three family members who were found dead at their home in the Drumgowna area of Co Louth have been named locally.

item.title: Vatican announces theme for 60th World Day of Social Communications
item.description:
“Preserving human voices and faces” is the theme for the 60th World Day of Social Communication, which will be celebrated on 17 May 2026, the Sunday before Pentecost.

Read all

item.description:
Pope Leo XIV meets with His Royal Highness Prince Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa, the Crown Prince and Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Bahrain in the Vatican.

item.title: Schools, parks closed as heavy rains lash eastern Spain
item.description: Schools, libraries and parks are closed in Valencia in eastern Spain after heavy rains prompted a red alert and fears of a repeat of deadly floods that hit the area last year.

item.title: Leinster House access works set to cost €180,000
item.description: Works to ensure all visitors to Leinster House are able to access the building independently are set to cost €180,000.

item.title: New appeal ordered for 4th First Nations man convicted in 1973 homicide, over a decade after his death
item.description: A First Nations man convicted of killing a man in Winnipeg more than 50 years ago is one step closer to having his name cleared following his own death, after Canada's justice minister ordered a new appeal in his case on Monday.
item.source:markdown:
![A young man in an old photograph.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7439521.1758983569!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/russell-woodhouse.jpg)
A First Nations man convicted of killing a man in Winnipeg more than 50 years ago is one step closer to having his name cleared following his own death, after Canada's justice minister ordered a new appeal in his case on Monday.

item.title: 'Grateful he's in my life' - Lowry is McIlroy's hero
item.description: Shane Lowry retained the Ryder Cup with that putt, but as he and Rory McIlroy explain to Greg Allen, this victory took three days of hard work and forbearance.

item.title: Two people killed in Ukrainian drone strike near Moscow
item.description: A fire sparked by a Ukrainian drone strike killed a child and grandmother in a town outside Moscow overnight, Russian authorities said today.

item.title: Canada halts importation of some European cheese following lumpy skin disease outbreak
item.description: The Canadian Food Inspection Agency has banned the importation of raw milk cheeses from France, Italy and Switzerland in an effort to prevent an outbreak of lumpy skin disease in cattle.

item.title: EU hails Moldova's 'European' choice in election
item.description: Victory for Moldova's ruling pro-EU party at key parliamentary elections was a "loud and clear" message from voters despite Russian meddling, European Union chief Antonio Costa said.

item.title: At least 11 killed as Typhoon Bualoi batters Vietnam
item.description: Typhoon Bualoi ripped roofs from buildings and uprooted electrical poles along Vietnam's coast, killing at least 11 people, local and national officials said today.

item.title: Namibia's Etosha National Park, home to critically endangered black rhino, engulfed in huge fire
item.description: Namibia has sent more than 500 soldiers to help battle a huge wildfire that has burned across 30 per cent of the country's best-known national park, home to hundreds of species including the critically endangered black rhino.
item.source:markdown:
![Rhino on plain with vegetation in foreground](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7646111.1759143361!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/474616196.jpg)
Namibia has sent more than 500 soldiers to help battle a huge wildfire that has burned across 30 per cent of the country's best-known national park, home to hundreds of species including the critically endangered black rhino.

item.title: Political will needed to end new HIV transmissions - HIVI
item.description: New HIV transmissions can be ended, but political will is needed, according to HIV Ireland. The first national HIV conference opens in the Aisling Hotel Dublin today.

item.title: At least 12 dead in Vietnam from Typhoon Bualoi
item.description: Heavy rain and strong winds from Typhoon Bualoi flooded roads, knocked off roofs and caused at least 12 deaths in central Vietnam, before weakening to a tropical storm that moved into Laos Monday, state media reported.

item.title: Sask. apologizes, agrees to pay $40M to survivors of Île-à-la-Crosse residential school
item.description: The Saskatchewan government is apologizing to former students of the Île-à-la-Crosse Boarding School and has agreed to pay $40.2 million in restitution to them and their families.
item.source:markdown:
![A man in an orange shirt holds up a sheet of paper.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7646522.1759170363!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpeg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/louis-gardiner.jpeg)
The Saskatchewan government is apologizing to former students of the Île-à-la-Crosse Boarding School and has agreed to pay $40.2 million in restitution to them and their families.

item.title: Moldova's pro-EU party wins election after campaign with Russian interference alleged
item.description: Moldova's pro-European ruling party won a resounding victory over its Russian-leaning rival in a key parliamentary election, results showed on Monday, a major boost for the country's bid to join the European Union and break away from Moscow's orbit.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman with auburn, chin-length hair poses for a photo while putting a piece of paper in a ballot box.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7646096.1759138585!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/2237531944.jpg)
Moldova's pro-European ruling party won a resounding victory over its Russian-leaning rival in a key parliamentary election, results showed on Monday, a major boost for the country's bid to join the European Union and break away from Moscow's orbit.

item.title: UK pledges £1.5 billion loan guarantee for Jaguar
item.description: Britain will back Jaguar Land Rover with a £1.5 billion loan guarantee to help support its supply chain in the wake of the luxury carmaker's production shutdown following a cyberattack.

item.title: Three candidates discuss defence, housing and safety
item.description: Follow live developments after the three presidential candidates take part in the first televised debate.

item.title: Bad Bunny to headline Super Bowl LX in 2026
item.description: Puerto Rican reggaeton star Bad Bunny will headline next year's Super Bowl halftime show in Santa Clara, California, the National Football League (NFL) in the US has announced.

item.title: Mi'kmaw chiefs say legislative changes raising tensions at Cape Breton protest site
item.description: The Assembly of Nova Scotia Mi'kmaw Chiefs says proposed amendments to provincial legislation are being made without consultation and some appear to be targeted at protesters on Hunter's Mountain in Cape Breton.
item.source:markdown:
![A group of people on a pile of logs with flags and drums](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7632607.1758916790!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/mi-kmaw-blockade-on-hunter-s-mountain.jpg)
The Assembly of Nova Scotia Mi'kmaw Chiefs says proposed amendments to provincial legislation are being made without consultation and some appear to be targeted at protesters on Hunter's Mountain in Cape Breton.

item.title: Under Trump 2.0, this looming U.S. government shutdown looks different
item.description: A shutdown of the U.S. government is looking all but inevitable and there’s growing concern the Trump administration is poised to use it as an opportunity to launch mass firings of federal employees.
item.source:markdown:
![Trump wears white golf shoes as he walks on the tarmac accompanied by a military officer in dress uniform. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645912.1759073340!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/trump.jpg)
A shutdown of the U.S. government is looking all but inevitable and there’s growing concern the Trump administration is poised to use it as an opportunity to launch mass firings of federal employees.

item.title: How 2 residential school survivors are reclaiming their culture through powwow dancing
item.description: Two residential school survivors in Saskatchewan danced powwow for the first time this summer as a part of their healing journey.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a silk dress with lace overlay and braided hair sits on a buffalo fur blanket, beside her is a number that she wore at a powwow.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7642511.1758743067!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/starla-starblanket.JPG)
Two residential school survivors in Saskatchewan danced powwow for the first time this summer as a part of their healing journey.

item.title: First Nation on smallest reserve in Canada has big dreams, ideas for the future
item.description: The Wolastoqiyik Wahsipekuk First Nation was historically allotted the smallest reserve in Canada, but its leaders and members are building projects to unify the community that is spread out across Quebec.
item.source:markdown:
![A young girl.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645121.1758915129!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/charlie-lavoie.jpg)
The Wolastoqiyik Wahsipekuk First Nation was historically allotted the smallest reserve in Canada, but its leaders and members are building projects to unify the community that is spread out across Quebec.

item.title: Trump announces Gaza peace plan, with Netanyahu backing
item.description: US President Donald Trump has said that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had agreed to back a US-sponsored Gaza peace proposal aimed at ending a nearly two-year-old war in the Palestinian enclave, including a ceasefire and the release of hostages held by Hamas.

item.title: Four dead, eight injured in US Mormon church shooting
item.description: A man who crashed his vehicle through the front doors of a Mormon church in Michigan opened fire with an assault rifle and set the church ablaze, killing at least four people and wounding at least eight others before dying in a shootout with police, officials said.

item.title: Reeves to announce paid work for unemployed youth in UK
item.description: The UK Labour Party conference continues in Liverpool, with the Chancellor of the Exchequer set to announce guaranteed paid work placements for unemployed young people.

item.title: Race against time to save Clare school from closure
item.description: A school in Co Clare has just one day to enrol new students to save it from closure next year.

item.title: Awareness campaign to assist sexual violence survivors
item.description: An information and awareness campaign directed at victims and survivors of sexual violence is due to be launched today.

item.title: Gardaí treating deaths in Finglas as murder-suicide case
item.description: Gardaí are treating the deaths of a father and daughter in Dublin on Saturday night as a case of murder-suicide. The bodies of the man, 50, and his five-year-old daughter were discovered in their home on Saturday night.

item.title: Gardaí treating deaths in Finglas as murder-suicide case
item.description: Gardaí are treating the deaths of a father and daughter in Dublin on Saturday night as a case of murder-suicide. The bodies of the man, 50, and his five-year-old daughter were discovered in their home on Saturday night.

item.title: Áras hopefuls discuss Gaza, housing and flags in debate
item.description: Gaza, housing, immigration and safety in Dublin were among the topics the three candidates took questions on during the first televised debate of the Presidential Election campaign.
item.source:markdown: Gaza, housing, immigration and safety in Dublin were among the topics the three candidates took questions on during the first televised debate of the Presidential Election campaign.

item.title: Lowry holes crucial putt as Europe win Ryder Cup
item.description: Shane Lowry holed the decisive putt to retain the Ryder Cup for Europe before the team went on to win the tournament outright by a 15-13 margin after holding off a dramatic fightback from the United States at Bethpage Black.

item.title: Towels, tunes and touchdowns as NFL hits Croke Park
item.description: Dublin was the latest stop on the American football global hype train today as fans from the US, Europe and further afield joined locals for the first regular-season game at Croke Park.

item.title: New York City Mayor Adams drops reelection bid
item.description: Embattled New York City Mayor Eric Adams, who has faced a federal bribery indictment and stunningly low approval ratings as the leader of the nation's largest city has dropped his reelection bid.

item.title: Spain's Valencia region on red alert for heavy rains
item.description: Spain's meteorological agency has put the eastern Valencia region under red alert for heavy rains, amid fears of a repeat of floods that killed 235 people last October in the area.

item.title: Denmark reports new drone sightings at military locations
item.description: The Danish defence ministry has said it again observed drones at several of its armed forces locations overnight, a day after NATO announced it would enhance its vigilance in the Baltic Sea region.

item.title: Two dead, nine injured in US Mormon church shooting
item.description: A gunman opened fire inside a Michigan church during Sunday services before apparently setting the building ablaze, killing at least two people and injuring nine before police shot him, authorities said.

item.title: China sentences former agricultural minister to death
item.description: China's former minister for agriculture has been sentenced to death on corruption charges, with a two-year reprieve, a court statement said.

item.title: 2025 Ryder Cup Day 3: Lowry retains Cup for Europe
item.description: Live updates from the final day of the Ryder Cup at Bethpage Black, with Europe on the cusp of victory

item.title: Israeli attacks kill 21 as Gaza death toll reaches 66,000
item.description: Israeli attacks have killed at least 21 people across Gaza today as health authorities in the enclave said the death toll from Israeli attacks had climbed to over 66,000 since October 2023.

item.title: Steelers confirm player involved in 'incident' in Dublin
item.description: A spokesman for American football team the Pittsburgh Steelers has confirmed that one of its players was involved in an incident in Dublin.

item.title: 'Supplementary' €250m needed for health service - Gloster
item.description: The Chief Executive of the HSE has said that "supplementary" funding will be required for the health service this year "probably in the order of about €250 million".

item.title: Ryder Cup announcer steps down over McIlroy chant
item.description: A crowd announcer at the Ryder Cup has stood down after leading an expletive-filled chant about Rory McIlroy.

item.title: NFL recap: Pittsburgh Steelers 24-21 Minnesota Vikings
item.description: Croke Park was the venue as the Pittsburgh Steelers held on for a 24-21 win over the Minnesota Vikings.

item.title: What Pikangikum's community hub means for food access, local jobs
item.description: Pikangikum First Nation is investing $30 million in a new grocery store, motel, and diner. The project is designed to strengthen food security, create jobs and keep economic revenues within the community.
item.source:markdown:
![A group of pile stand on pavement](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645336.1758922430!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/pikangikum-first-nation.jpg)
Pikangikum First Nation is investing $30 million in a new grocery store, motel, and diner. The project is designed to strengthen food security, create jobs and keep economic revenues within the community.

item.title: 4 dead, 8 wounded in shooting and fire at Michigan church, police say
item.description: A gunman opened fire inside a Michigan church during a Sunday service before apparently setting the building ablaze, authorities said, killing at least four people and injuring eight others before police shot him.

item.title: Limerick tees off events as Adare to host next Ryder Cup
item.description: The eyes of the golfing world are on New York for the final day of the 2025 Ryder Cup at Bethpage Black, but attention will then turn to a village in Co Limerick which is set to host the tournament in 2027.

item.title: Joyce Echaquan's death sparked change. But 5 years later, change is still just beginning
item.description: Joyce Echaquan's death in 2020 and the shocking footage preceding it that she managed to livestream, amplified the conversation around systemic racism in Quebec. Five years later, that conversation is far from over.
item.source:markdown:
![A person wearing a purple shirt. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645783.1759021142!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/joyce-echaquan.jpg)
Joyce Echaquan's death in 2020 and the shocking footage preceding it that she managed to livestream, amplified the conversation around systemic racism in Quebec. Five years later, that conversation is far from over.

item.title: ‘We don’t believe in giving up’ deputy UN chief tells New York festival crowd
item.description: Deputy UN Secretary-General Amina Mohammed thanked the crowd at New York’s Global Citizen Festival on Saturday for using their voice for justice and “refusing to give up on a better world.”
item.source:markdown: Deputy UN Secretary-General Amina Mohammed thanked the crowd at New York’s Global Citizen Festival on Saturday for using their voice for justice and “refusing to give up on a better world.”

item.title: Irish peacekeepers could be sent to Ukraine 'if required'
item.description: The Minister for Defence has said Ireland could send peacekeepers to Ukraine if it was called to do so as part of any peace deal in the war with Russia.

item.title: Pope prays for victims of typhoon in Asia
item.description:
Pope Leo prays for those affected by a typhoon that has struck the Phiippines, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Vietnam and parts of China. He also announces that St John Henry Newman will be declared Doctor of the Church on the 1st November.

Read all

item.title: Nigeria: Lagos Ecclesiastical Province celebrates Jubilee of Catechists
item.description:
Over the weekend, about 200 catechists, priests, religious and other lay faithful gathered at St Anthony Catholic Church, Shagamu for the celebration of the Jubilee of Catechists in the Jubilee Year of Hope.

Read all

item.title: Gavin says vision to ensure everyone has voice in society
item.description: Fianna Fáil presidential candidate Jim Gavin has said his vision is to ensure that every person from every section of society has a voice.

item.title: Tanzania: Bishops caution priests against partisan politics and campaigns
item.description:
The Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC) has issued a directive prohibiting Catholic priests, religious sisters, Brothers, and seminarians from participating in partisan politics or campaigns. The directive also discourages clergy and seminarians from wearing political party campaign regalia.

Read all

item.title: Denmark bans drone flights after fresh drone sightings at military bases
item.description: Denmark ordered a ban on Sunday on civil drone flights, after drones were observed at several military facilities overnight, following a week in which drone sorties caused the temporary closures of several Danish airports.

item.title: Palestinian death toll tops 66,000 as Israel's Netanyahu prepares to meet with Trump in the U.S.
item.description: Over 66,000 Palestinians have been killed in the Israel-Hamas war, Gaza’s Health Ministry said Sunday, a day before Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu heads to the White House for talks with U.S. President Donald Trump on halting Israel’s ongoing offensive in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Moldovans begin voting in high-stakes election
item.description: Moldovans have begun voting in a parliamentary election that could have a major impact on the government's quest to join the European Union, as a popular pro-Russian group seeks to steer the small nation away from closer ties with the bloc.

item.title: Moldova's pro-EU party ahead in key polls - partial count
item.description: Moldova's ruling party pulled ahead of the pro-Russian opposition as votes cast in a key parliamentary election were counted, but it looked set to fall short of the majority it wants in order to push for membership of the European Union.

item.title: August and everything after: Season debate still rages
item.description: The split-season debate has moved onto a discussion regarding the condensed inter-county season. What is the GAA's next move with the playing schedule?

item.title: Pope at Mass: Catechists accompany our faith journey throughout life
item.description:
At Mass for the Jubilee of Catechists, Pope Leo XIV praises those who seek to accompany others in the faith, and invites all Christians to help one another learn to believe, hope, and then love.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: 40 dead, 124 injured following political rally stampede in India
item.description: The death toll following a stampede at a political rally for a popular Indian actor and politician in the southern state of Tamil Nadu has climbed to 40, the state’s health minister said Sunday, as medics treated at least 124 injured in hospitals.

item.title: Scheffler to face McIlroy in Sunday's singles
item.description: World number one Scottie Scheffler will have to earn his first point at this year's Ryder Cup the hard way after being paired against Rory McIlroy in Sunday's singles.

item.title: SF calls for €100k NMH bike shed tender to be scrapped
item.description: Sinn Féin has called for a tender for a new €100,000 bike shed at the National Maternity Hospital to be scrapped.

item.title: Double gold for Irish rowers at World Championships
item.description: There was double gold joy for Ireland at the World Rowing Championships in Shanghai as Fiona Murtagh in the women's singles and Fintan McCarthy and Mags Cremen in the mixed double sculls both assumed top place on their respective podiums.

item.title: Russian govt dismisses Zelensky's 'bomb shelter' threats
item.description: The Russian government has dismissed threats by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky that the Kremlin and its officials are under threat from attack by Ukraine and its weaponry.

item.title: Blessed Pietro Paolo Oros, a witness to communion in a divided world
item.description:
On Saturday morning, 27 September in Bilky, Ukraine, the Divine Liturgy was celebrated for the beatification of a priest who was martyred under the communist regime, killed in 1953 at just 36 years old. Cardinal Grzegorz Ryś, representing Pope Leo, recalled how the new Blessed became a “bridge” amidst divisions and conflicts.

Read all

Cardinal Grzegorz Ryś, representing Pope Leo, recalled how the new Blessed became a “bridge” amidst divisions and conflicts.

item.title: Crisis in Israel could shape country for generation
item.description: As Israel becomes more isolated internationally, with 150 countries now recognising a Palestinian state, the country is in the grip of an internal and external crisis that could shape it for a generation, writes Tony Connelly.

item.title: Stakes are high for Gavin on campaign launch day
item.description: There are some august former high-ranking members of the Defence Forces who without much prompting will talk at length about Jim Gavin's leadership qualities, writes Political Correspondent Mícheál Lehane.

item.title: Where do our taxes go and where will they go in future?
item.description: Spending money wisely is perhaps one of the most important jobs for any government. Economic and Public Affairs Editor David Murphy looks at where Ireland's taxes go and where they will go in future.

item.title: Is it good economics to pay €10 million for an NFL match?
item.description: Thousands of American tourists came to Dublin this weekend to watch the Pittsburgh Steelers challenge the Minnesota Vikings in Croke Park.

item.title: Climate Week goes on as Trump blasts 'con job'
item.description: It was an unusual start to the annual Climate Week with US President Donald Trump labelling climate change "a hoax" and "the greatest con job". While spirits weren't dampened, America's divergence sees the conversation shift from decarbonisation to energy security, writes Yvonne Murray.

item.title: The Walsh Sisters: 'It's special to be a part of this'
item.description: The TV adaptation of Marian Keyes' Walsh Sisters books begins tonight on RTÉ One. John Byrne meets Louisa Harland and Caroline Menton, who play sisters Anna and Rachel.

item.title: Daycare in Denmark is a basic right. Could Canada offer the same?
item.description: With months ticking down to the goal of $10-per-day daycare across Canada, there are at least five provinces who have yet to meet that goal. And there is mounting evidence from other countries that Canada’s market-based approach risks wasting public dollars — and worsening quality of care.

item.title: Indian law enforcement officials collaborating with Canada, confirms foreign affairs minister
item.description: Foreign Affairs Minister Anita Anand confirmed that Indian law enforcement officials are actively collaborating with Canada as the two countries continue to thaw a once-icy relationship following allegations that Indian agents were linked to an extrajudicial killing on Canadian soil.

item.title: Vatican Observatory’s new head talks wars, galaxies, and humanity’s fate
item.description: In 1990, the future director of the Vatican Observatory was living in a refugee camp in Jordan.
item.source:markdown: In 1990, the future director of the Vatican Observatory was living in a refugee camp in Jordan.

item.title: UN sanctions return to hit Iran after nuclear talks fail
item.description: Widespread UN sanctions against Iran returned into force for the first time in a decade, after last-ditch nuclear talks with Western powers failed to produce a breakthrough.

item.title: Tributes paid to Donegal fisherman after body recovered
item.description: Tributes have been paid to the fisherman who lost his life off the northwest coast, who has been named locally as Kevin McCloskey.

item.title: Bodies found in Dublin believed to be father and daughter
item.description: Gardaí believe the bodies of a man and child discovered at a house in Finglas in Dublin are those of a father and his daughter.

item.title: McSweeney calls on UK govt to implement Philomena's Law
item.description: Actor Siobhán McSweeney has called on the British government to implement legislation that would give survivors of mother-and-baby homes, now living in the UK, access to Irish Government compensation.

item.title: UN resumes sanctions on Iran after failed last-minute nuclear talks
item.description: The United Nations reimposed sanctions on Iran early Sunday over its nuclear program, further squeezing the Islamic Republic as its people increasingly find themselves priced out of the food they need to survive and worried about their futures.

item.title: Bodies of man and young child found at house in Dublin
item.description: Gardaí are investigating after two bodies were discovered at a house in Finglas in Dublin tonight.

item.title: Dozens killed in stampede at political rally in India
item.description: At least 36 people were killed and more than 50 injured in a stampede at a rally in Tamil Nadu in India held by actor Vijay, who is campaigning for election, the chief minister of Tamil Nadu said.

item.title: Israel-Premier Tech cycling team excluded from race in Italy over safety concerns
item.description: Cycling team Israel-Premier Tech has been excluded from an upcoming race in Italy over concerns about pro-Palestinian protests and disruption if the team was to participate.

item.title: Trump orders deployment of troops to Portland
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he was directing Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth to send troops to Portland, Oregon and to protect federal immigration facilities against "domestic terrorists", saying he was authorising them to use "full force, if necessary".

item.title: England crush Canada to claim World Cup glory at last
item.description: Ellie Kildunne scored a wonder try as England banished their World Cup demons to be crowned champions by crushing Canada 33-13 at Twickenham.

item.title: 'Colm's memory lives on' - service honours organ donors
item.description: Over one thousand people gathered for a service of remembrance and thanksgiving to honour organ donors.

item.title: Ukraine seeking to buy €76bn worth of US weapons
item.description: Ukraine is seeking to purchase €76bn worth of US weapons to support its defence against Russia in the war that has now been grinding on for three-and-a-half years.

item.title: Holy See says arms race ‘unacceptable’ and risks ‘nuclear catastrophe'
item.description:
In his two speeches at the United Nations, the Holy See Secretary for Relations with States and International Organisations urges the ratification of a treaty banning nuclear tests, and expresses concern about an artificial intelligence 'arms race'.

Read all

In his two speeches at the United Nations, the Holy See Secretary for Relations with States and International Organisations urges the ratification of a treaty banning nuclear tests, and expresses concern about an artificial intelligence 'arms race'.

item.title: Man dies weeks after being struck by car in Monaghan
item.description: A 47-year-old man has died from the injuries he sustained in a road traffic collision in Monaghan earlier this month.

item.title: Áras candidates voice support for a united Ireland
item.description: All three Presidential Election candidates have said they would like to see a united Ireland in the future, when questioned while out on the campaign trail across the country.

item.title: Oregon officials, residents slam 'ridiculous' Trump order to send troops into Portland
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said Saturday he will send troops to Portland, Ore., "authorizing Full Force, if necessary" to handle "domestic terrorists" as he expands his controversial deployments to more American cities.

item.title: Govt to offer up to €10k for families to drop IP claim
item.description: Minister for Justice Jim O'Callaghan has signed an order that will see asylum seekers and their families offered up to €10,000 to drop their claim for international protection.

item.title: 'Best news' for Huntington's disease community comes with unanswered questions
item.description: An experimental gene therapy seems to show potential to slow the debilitating progression of Huntington's disease, a European biotech company that developed the new treatment says.

item.title: Hamas says it has not received US Gaza ceasefire plan
item.description: Israeli attacks have killed 74 people in Gaza in the past day, health officials in the enclave have said, while Hamas said it has not received US President Donald Trump's Gaza ceasefire plan.

item.title: ‘The UN is in a state of crisis’ warns Indian senior government minister
item.description: In his address to the General Assembly, Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, India’s Minister for External Affairs outlined the failings of a “gridlocked” UN, whilst asserting the need for more international cooperation and a reformed Organisation.
item.source:markdown: In his address to the General Assembly, Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, India’s Minister for External Affairs outlined the failings of a “gridlocked” UN, whilst asserting the need for more international cooperation and a reformed Organisation.

item.title: Russia’s Lavrov says UN as relevant as ever in ‘age of multipolarity’
item.description: Widespread violations of the principle of the equality of states are the cause of crises and conflicts, Russian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Sergey Lavrov, told the General Assembly on Saturday. Mr Lavrov added that the founding principles of the UN are as relevant as ever in today’s “age of multipolarity.”
item.source:markdown: Widespread violations of the principle of the equality of states are the cause of crises and conflicts, Russian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Sergey Lavrov, told the General Assembly on Saturday. Mr Lavrov added that the founding principles of the UN are as relevant as ever in today’s “age of multipolarity.”

item.title: Current world order ‘reflects a bygone era,’ says Cuban Foreign Minister
item.description: Bruno Rodríguez Parilla, in his address to the General Assembly on Saturday, said that there can be no effective global response to serious challenges because the current world order "reflects a bygone era, when most developing countries did not even exist as independent states."
item.source:markdown: Bruno Rodríguez Parilla, in his address to the General Assembly on Saturday, said that there can be no effective global response to serious challenges because the current world order "reflects a bygone era, when most developing countries did not even exist as independent states."

item.title: New drone sightings over Denmark's biggest military base
item.description: Unidentified drones flew over Danish military sites including its biggest base during the night, the latest in a slew of sightings officials have called a "hybrid attack" and hinted at possible Russian involvement.

item.title: NATO to increase Baltic presence after drone incidents
item.description: NATO has said it is upgrading its mission in the Baltic Sea with an air-defence frigate and other assets in response to drone incursions in Denmark.

item.title: 'No decisions' made over carers allowance in Budget
item.description: The Minister for Finance has said that "no decisions" have been made on changes to the carers allowance in this year's budget.

item.title: 2025 Ryder Cup Day 2 recap - USA 4.5 Europe 11.5
item.description: The action from the second day of the 2025 Ryder Cup where Team Europe began with a three-point lead over their hosts at Bethpage Black.

item.title: As it happened: Áras candidates campaign across country
item.description: Coverage of all today's developments on the Presidential Election as the three candidates go on the campaign trail in Dublin and Cork.

item.title: Trump administration asks U.S. Supreme Court to uphold order aimed at ending birthright citizenship
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration is asking the Supreme Court to uphold his birthright citizenship order declaring that children born to parents who are in the United States illegally or temporarily are not American citizens.

item.description:

item.title: International Paralympic Committee lifts partial suspensions of Russia, Belarus
item.description: The International Paralympic Committee has lifted the partial suspensions of Russia and Belarus. The IPC general assembly in Seoul, South Korea, on Saturday first voted against a full suspension for Russia by 111 to 55, with 11 abstentions, and then voted against a partial suspension by 91-77 (with eight abstentions).

item.title: Body found in search for missing fisherman in Donegal Bay
item.description: A body has been recovered in the search for a missing fisherman off the northwest coast.

item.title: McCarthy adds to family medal haul with World bronze
item.description: Jake McCarthy has won bronze in the men's lightweight singles at the World Rowing Championships in Shanghai.

item.title: Regina youth use art to express meaning of truth and reconciliation
item.description: The North Central Strong youth advocacy committee came together earlier this month at the mâmawêyatitân centre for an ink press workshop where they created linocut pieces that were pressed onto orange poster board cut into the shape of shirts.

![A picture of orange shirts cut out and stamped with linocut art work](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7643863.1758836115!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/orange-shirt-trc-youth-art.jpg)
The North Central Strong youth advocacy committee came together earlier this month at the mâmawêyatitân centre for an ink press workshop where they created linocut pieces that were pressed onto orange poster board cut into the shape of shirts.

item.title: Moldova's high-stakes vote: Democracy v disinformation
item.description: Moldovan President Maia Sandu has told RTÉ News that Russia has tried to influence tomorrow's high-stakes parliamentary election in the country through a campaign of bribery and disinformation about the European Union.

item.title: 'Unacceptable' to ignore human crisis in Gaza - Obama
item.description: Former US president Barack Obama has said there is no military rationale right now for continuing to pummel what is already broken in Gaza, and he said it was unacceptable to ignore the human crisis that is happening there.

item.title: Pairings confirmed for Saturday's Ryder Cup foursomes
item.description: European captain Luke Donald insists making history on day one will count for little if his team do not go on to win the Ryder Cup.

item.title: PSNI arrests thousands under new domestic violence laws
item.description: Police in Northern Ireland made more than 5,000 arrests during the past three years under new legislation aimed at tackling violence against women and girls.

item.title: 99 Problems: Why Ben & Jerry's is at war with Unilever
item.description: The man who put 'Jerry' into 'Ben & Jerry's' has walked away from the company he co-founded in a dispute that many industry-watchers predicted 25 years ago, writes Adam Maguire.

item.title: West Bank: Tales of the dispossessed
item.description: Continuous expansion by Israel of settlements in the West Bank is pushing Palestinians out of their homes and move elsewhere. The pattern consists of settler attacks on Palestinian farms and villages, often aided and abetted, say locals, by the Israeli military.

item.title: Turbulence ahead as opinions clash over passenger cap
item.description: The war of words over Dublin Airport's controversial passenger cap shows no sign of easing up anytime soon, amid very conflicting opinions on what should happen.

item.title: Meet the brothers at war in House of Guinness
item.description: Are Northern Irish actor Anthony Boyle and his English co-star Louis Partridge the Liam and Noel Gallagher of House of Guinness?

item.title: Perrie on being a solo artist: You have to own the room
item.description: We chatted to Little Mix star Perrie Edwards as she prepared to release Perrie, her eagerly-anticipated debut album, about "starting from scratch" as a solo artist, learning to trust her intuition and her love for her former bandmates.

item.title: Amid threats of annexation, could Canada and Greenland grow closer?
item.description: Canada and Greenland already had plenty in common before facing threats of annexation from the White House — but all that attention could make for a timely reason to strengthen a key relationship. CBC's Emma Godmere traveled to Greenland’s capital of Nuuk to hear from residents about being in the international spotlight and pursuing stronger ties with Canada.

item.title: Language revitalization is in the cards for this northern B.C. First Nation
item.description: Cheyenne Kaiser-Conant, a member of the Prophet River First Nation in northern B.C., says that resources for learning the Beaver language are slim. That's why she helped create a new tool to help other learners like herself: a deck of playing cards meant to bring the language to life.
item.source:markdown:
![A close-up of a person's hands holding a playing card.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7642858.1758748843!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/beaver-language-cards.jpg)
Cheyenne Kaiser-Conant, a member of the Prophet River First Nation in northern B.C., says that resources for learning the Beaver language are slim. That's why she helped create a new tool to help other learners like herself: a deck of playing cards meant to bring the language to life.

item.title: SNL returns next week. When the show debuted, it didn't shy away from assassination talk
item.description: Donald Trump, who hosted Saturday Night Live twice before becoming president, has consistently complained about his treatment on the sketch comedy show. The show returns next week, and Trump's aggressive communications regulator will likely take notice.

item.title: Sask.-based group rematriating the buffalo at national museum
item.description: The Wahkohtowin Buffalo and Moose Hide Experience at the Canada Agriculture and Food Museum is inviting Indigenous organizations and members of the public to help prepare animal hides for tanning. It's part of the Ottawa museum's efforts to mark the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.
item.source:markdown:

The Wahkohtowin Buffalo and Moose Hide Experience at the Canada Agriculture and Food Museum is inviting Indigenous organizations and members of the public to help prepare animal hides for tanning. It's part of the Ottawa museum's efforts to mark the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.

item.title: UN sanctions on Iran loom after vote to delay fails
item.description: UN sanctions on Iran are set to be reimposed, Britain's UN envoy has said, after a Russian and Chinese Security Council resolution to delay them failed, prompting Tehran to warn that the West bore responsibility for any consequences after nuclear talks floundered.

item.title: Guinea Supreme Court confirms vote to change constitution
item.description: Guinea's Supreme Court confirmed the result of a referendum to approve a new constitution in the junta-ruled country, saying it was backed by an overwhelming majority of voters.

item.title: How a former FBI director ended up on Trump’s enemy list
item.description: In an apparent escalation of U.S. President Donald Trump’s attacks on his political enemies, former FBI director James Comey has now been indicted on criminal charges. For The National, CBC’s Lyndsay Duncombe lays out a timeline of how it got to this point.

item.title: MSF suspend activity in Gaza City amid Israeli offensive
item.description: Medical charity Doctors without Borders (MSF) said Friday it had been forced to suspend its work in Gaza City because of the ongoing Israeli offensive there.

item.title: Podcast: Rising authoritarianism, Kneecap and Eurovision
item.description: An expert in international relations has told RTÉ's Behind the Story podcast it is "extremely alarming" that Donald Trump has the full force of the US government behind him for another three years.

item.title: Sask. First Nations leaders demand answers from FSIN over audit into $34M of questionable spending
item.description: A group of First Nation chiefs and councillors who met in Saskatoon Friday accuse the leadership of the Federation of Sovereign Indigenous Nations of refusing to address allegations of mismanagement.

item.title: Ireland to prevent entry of Israeli ministers - Taoiseach
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has told the UN General Assembly that Ireland will act to prevent members of the Israeli government who are "engaged in the unfolding disaster in Gaza" from entering Ireland.

item.title: Woman fell off Cliffs of Moher avoiding puddle - inquest
item.description: A 20-year-old University of Edinburgh student slipped and fell to her death while walking at the side of a "huge puddle" on a muddy part of a trail beside the cliff edge at the Cliffs of Moher in May 2024, an inquest has heard.

item.title: McIlroy takes centre stage as Europe take control in NY
item.description: Rory McIlroy was at the centre of controversy and the action as Europe controlled the opening day of the Ryder Cup at Bethpage Black.

item.title: The Netherlands returns 'Java Man,' thousands of colonial-era fossils taken from Indonesia
item.description: The Dutch government has agreed to return thousands of fossils to Indonesia from a world-renowned collection, after a commission ruled they were removed in the colonial era "against the will of the people," the education ministry announced on Friday.

item.title: Increase in over-65s 'couch surfing' amid homelessness
item.description: The Simon Communities has said action is required now to tackle over 65s becoming homeless, before the situation gets out of control.

item.title: EU steps up 'drone wall' plans after Russian incursions
item.description: EU countries have agreed on the urgent need to create a "wall" of anti-drone defences, after airspace violations by Russia rattled eastern members.

item.title: Cree Nation joins bid to redevelop Hudson’s Bay building
item.description: The James Bay Eeyou Corporation and JHD Real Estate propose to transform the Hudson’s Bay building in downtown Montreal into a hotel, a museum celebrating Cree culture, and subsidized housing for Indigenous students.

item.title: Why the world is watching as China pledges emissions cuts
item.description: China, the world’s largest polluter, just made a historic move: for the first time, the country is pledging actual cuts to its greenhouse gas emissions. CBC's Johanna Wagstaffe breaks down what this means for global climate action and how it compares to the U.S. and Canada.

item.title: Key peace process adviser Martin Mansergh dies aged 78
item.description: Former minister of state and key Fianna Fáil adviser Martin Mansergh has died aged 78.

item.description: The former high school football player who killed four people inside a Manhattan office tower that houses the headquarters of the NFL, was suffering from the degenerative brain disease CTE, New York's medical examiner said Friday.

item.description: Scores of delegates exited the hall of the United Nations General Assembly as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu walked up to the podium to give his speech.

item.description: Russia has accused Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky of making "irresponsible" threats after he said Moscow's top officials should check for bomb shelters near the Kremlin if the country does not stop its offensive on Ukraine.

item.title: Gaza: Four more hospitals shut amid ongoing Israeli offensive
item.description: The escalating Israeli military offensive in Gaza City continues to overwhelm medical professionals there, with four more hospitals forced to shut down this month alone in the north of the war-torn enclave, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Resolution to avoid ‘snapback’ of UN sanctions on Iran fails
item.description: The UN Security Council has voted down an effort by China and Russia to extend sanctions relief to Iran for six months under the nuclear deal – formally known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. The so-called “snapback” mechanism remains in force which will see sanctions reimposed on Tehran this weekend, following the termination of the JCPOA. Follow our live coverage below; UN News app users can go here.

item.title: UN warns time running out for families with terrorist ties stranded in Syria camps
item.description: Six years after the defeat of ISIL, also known as Daesh, tens of thousands of people with alleged or actual ties to the terrorist group remain detained in camps in northeast Syria in dire conditions that continue to worsen.
item.source:markdown: Six years after the defeat of ISIL, also known as Daesh, tens of thousands of people with alleged or actual ties to the terrorist group remain detained in camps in northeast Syria in dire conditions that continue to worsen.

item.title: Pakistan’s Prime Minister warns of regional tensions, calls for ceasefire in Gaza
item.description: Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif told the United Nations General Assembly on Friday that the world faces “testing times” marked by conflict, terrorism, and climate change, while urging urgent action for peace in South Asia, the Middle East and beyond.
item.source:markdown: Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif told the United Nations General Assembly on Friday that the world faces “testing times” marked by conflict, terrorism, and climate change, while urging urgent action for peace in South Asia, the Middle East and beyond.

item.title: Intensifying threat looms large as UN highlights the world’s growing nuclear arsenals
item.description: The UN Secretary General on Friday warned a high-level meeting in New York focused on ridding the world of nuclear weapons that the threat is only “accelerating and evolving”.

item.title: Netanyahu hails Israel’s ‘stunning comeback’ after 7 October attacks, vows to ‘finish the job’
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told the UN General Assembly on Friday that Israel had rebounded from “its darkest day” to deliver “one of the most stunning military comebacks in history,” declaring that his country will not rest until Hamas is eliminated and hostages are freed.
item.source:markdown: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told the UN General Assembly on Friday that Israel had rebounded from “its darkest day” to deliver “one of the most stunning military comebacks in history,” declaring that his country will not rest until Hamas is eliminated and hostages are freed.

item.title: ‘The extraordinary power of ordinary people’: World leaders spotlight youth as agents of progress
item.description: Young people are at the heart of the world’s most urgent challenges, and on Friday, their role in shaping solutions took centre stage at the UN General Assembly. World leaders spoke of the remarkable promise held by today’s generation, even as they acknowledged the persistent barriers millions of children and youth face in accessing education, healthcare and political voice.
