item.description: After her shock murder on Sunday night's episode of The Traitor's Ireland, Amy has said she believes the remaining Traitors are still hiding in plain sight.

item.title: SEAI appeals to organisations to retrofit facilities
item.description: One of the agencies charged with reducing the country's carbon footprint is appealing to sports clubs, charities, community and cultural organisations to draw up plans to retrofit their facilities, saying it has millions of euro available to distribute to them in grants.

item.title: A GTA school board banned Every Child Matters flags. Now, some families are speaking out
item.description: On the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation this year, "Every Child Matters" flags won’t be on display at Dufferin-Peel Catholic schools after the board updated its flag protocol earlier this year, restricting what flags can be displayed.

item.description: As the Trump administration moves to limit some skilled workers from entering the U.S. on a specialized visa, the Canadian tech sector is champing at the bit — hoping the new restriction will lure talent up north.

item.description: A Canadian expert on Russian warfare says he believes a direct line can be drawn between Moscow's repeated testing of the airspace belonging to NATO allies in Eastern Europe and the Pentagon's recent, quietly announced plan to cut security assistance to the Baltic states.

item.title: Moving stories in motion pictures capture experiences with cancer in Ontario's Inuit community
item.description: A new six-part video series from the Ontario Inuit Cancer Program looks to expand education on cancer prevention, recovery and care for Inuit living in the province. The organization hopes the videos can help reduce barriers to accessing cancer care for the community.

item.description: Super Typhoon Ragasa brought heavy rain and triggered landslides in the northern Philippines on Monday as it made landfall with sustained winds measuring 215 km/h and gusts of up to 295 km/h. One of this year's strongest typhoons, Ragasa is forecast to remain in the South China Sea at least into Wednesday while skirting south of Taiwan and Hong Kong before hitting the Chinese mainland.

item.title: Mozambique: Laudato Si’ initiative inspires ecumenical gathering for peace and the environment
item.description:
The Ecumenical Worship for the Season of Creation recently brought together over a hundred Christians from various denominations in Nampula, northern Mozambique. This gathering served as a moment for prayer and a powerful display of solidarity in caring for creation, inspired by the encyclical, “Laudato Si’”. Additionally, the event was an opportunity for participants to advocate for peace in Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado Province.

item.title: Pakistan officials, rights group condemn killing of 3 transgender women

item.title: Whitehorse housing facility for women and families dedicated to late Ta'an Kwäch'än leader
item.description: With 15 units, the facility provides short-term and emergency housing for Indigenous women and families including those fleeing abuse or recovering from addiction. It's in honour of the late Ta'an Kwäch'än Elder.

item.title: Situation in Gaza City 'like a horror movie', says doctor
item.description: An Australian doctor working at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City has said the situation there is "like a horror movie".

item.title: Women for Peace: Voices of hope and humanity
item.description:
"Women for Peace" is a unique concept-concert that unites voices from around the world to promote reconciliation, hope, and solidarity and peace. The initiative blends opera and storytelling to highlight women as agents of peace. It uses music as a universal language capable of bridging cultures, inspiring reflection, and sending a clear message: peace is not a luxury, it is a human necessity.

Read all

item.title: Holy Cross Missionaries invite Catholics to pray global rosary for peace
item.description:
As the Church celebrates the Marian month of October, the Congregation of Holy Cross is inviting families to pray together for peace, especially on October 22, feast of Pope St. John Paul II.

Read all

item.title: Stellantis reports data breach affecting North American customers
item.description: Stellantis detected unauthorized access to a third-party service provider's platform that supports its North American customer service operations, the company said in a statement on Sunday.

item.title: As it happened: Catherine Connolly launches campaign
item.description: Welcome to our live coverage on the latest on the race for Áras an Uachtaráin.

item.title: GRA, RACO and Women's Aid call for end to sale of location data
item.description: Women's Aid, the Garda Representative Association and RACO – which represents officers in the Defence Forces - have all called for action to be taken to prevent the sale of precise smartphone location data.

item.title: 30 years of advancing gender equality: Achievements, setbacks, and the road ahead
item.description: In the three decades since the groundbreaking Beijing Declaration on women’s rights was adopted by the nations of the world, great progress has been made but women and girls still face unacceptable levels of violence and discrimination. At this year’s General Assembly, UN delegates will reflect on the achievements made and raise awareness about the huge amount of work that still needs to be done.

item.title: UN marks 80th anniversary of its founding
item.description: Music, memories and messages of peace filled the UN General Assembly Hall on Monday as the world body commemorated 80 years since its founding.

item.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Take ‘immediate steps’ to de-escalate tensions over Russia-Ukraine war, urges Jenča
item.description: The Security Council met in New York in emergency session on Monday after planes from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) intercepted three Russia jets in Estonian airspace last Friday, according to the Estonian Government. Referencing the intensifying attacks by Russia on Ukraine and reported casualties inside Russia, “the world simply cannot afford such danger to spiral out of control,” said Assistant Secretary-General Miroslav Jenča. Follow the meeting coverage live below, and UN News app users can click here.

item.title: World News in Brief: Call for new Haiti force, Ukraine and Sudan war updates, ‘disturbing’ sentence for China blogger
item.description: Without greater international engagement, Haiti risks sliding deeper into crisis, leaders warned on Monday at a meeting in New York convened to address the country’s security collapse.

item.title: Offensive shutters nearly half of all malnutrition centres in and around Gaza City
item.description: Hostilities between Israeli forces and Hamas have led to the shuttering of almost half of all malnutrition centres in and around Gaza City, the northern area of the Strip where famine was declared a month ago.

item.title: High-level week opens with celebration of women’s empowerment
item.description: Only the fifth woman to preside over the UN General Assembly in its 80-year history has praised the courage of those “who fought for every phrase, every word in the Beijing Declaration,” marking the 30th Anniversary of the pivotal international conference on women’s empowerment.

item.title: Recommit to a two-State solution for Israel-Palestine conflict, ‘before it’s too late’: Guterres
item.description: The time has come to free the 48 hostages still being held by Hamas in Gaza and to stop the bombing, massacres and displacement in the embattled enclave, French President Emmanual Macron told delegates in the UN General Assembly Hall on Monday.

item.title: Nunavut's territorial election set for Oct. 27, campaign begins Monday
item.description: The writ has dropped, marking the start of the campaign to elect the next territorial government.

item.title: Jim Gavin 'taking a stand' against online smears
item.description: Fianna Fáil presidential candidate Jim Gavin has criticised social media posts circulating about him, saying his family and friends should not be subject to online abuse and smears.

item.title: Grocery price inflation rises to 6.3% from 5.4%

item.title: 2 Gaza City hospitals forced to halt operations as Israeli offensive intensifies: Health Ministry
item.description: Two Gaza City hospitals have been taken out of service due to Israel's escalation of its ground offensive and damage caused by continued Israeli bombing, the enclave's Health Ministry said, as tanks advanced deeper into the territory.

item.title: Eight Swedish glaciers disappeared in 2024, expert says

item.title: Vatican: Appeal trial for London property case opens Monday

On September 22, in the new chambers of the Vatican Tribunal, the second chapter of the high-profile case over the London property deal begins. The first trial ended in December 2023 with ten convictions. Now comes the appeal phase, starting with five hearings this week.

item.title: How a 'made for television' state visit gave Trump what he wanted — and acted like a 'shield' for the U.K.
item.description: Donald Trump's state visit to the U.K. may have given U.S. president much of what he wished for, surrounding him in the pomp and circumstance of royalty. item.title: Canada needs all evidence assessed before recognizing genocide in Gaza, says incoming UN ambassador
item.description: Incoming UN Ambassador David Lametti says Canada needs "all the evidence to come in" and be assessed before it can recognize whether Israel is committing a genocide in Gaza — and the first benchmark decisions are usually a UN resolution or a ruling from the International Court of Justice.

item.title: International students share cramped rental accommodation
item.description: Third level institutions in Limerick say that they are assisting up to 16 international students who have found themselves sharing in what was a two-bedroomed house.

item.title: Indigenous-led Downtown Eastside programs get 6-month funding extension
item.description: An Indigenous-led organization for unhoused residents of Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside says it has six more months to figure out how to continue drop-in services for its clients.

item.title: Podcast: Jimmy Kimmel suspension and phone data for sale
item.description: As the fallout from ABC's decision to suspend Jimmy Kimmel continues, several prominent US TV hosts used their platforms on Thursday night to criticise the decision to suspend him.

item.title: Bertie Ahern coy on support for Jim Gavin's Áras campaign
item.description: Former taoiseach Bertie Ahern was reluctant to express clear support when asked whether he would be giving his backing to Fianna Fáil's presidential candidate Jim Gavin, after his own bid for the party's nomination failed.

item.title: More to be done, but reconciliation with Indigenous communities on the right track, says Montreal
item.description: When its strategy for reconciliation with Indigenous people was launched in 2020, the Valérie Plante administration set out 125 actions to improve services and partnerships with these communities. Though some have noticed a shift in attitude, issues like red tape linger.

item.title: Global agreement to protect the oceans set to take effect after 60th ratification
item.description: The first treaty to protect marine diversity in international waters will come into force early next year, after Morocco became the 60th nation to ratify the agreement on Friday.

item.title: Trailblazing McPhillips ready for world final stage
item.description: It has been a week to remember for Cian McPhillips, lowering the 800m national record and making history by storming into a World Championship final. What can the Longford man hope to achieve at Japan's National Stadium?

item.title: U.S. vetoes U.N. ceasefire resolution as Gaza crisis deepens
item.description:
The United States has vetoed a UN Security Council resolution calling for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza and the release of hostages.

Read all

item.title: Pope invites Rome Diocese to promote pastoral ministry that welcomes all
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV addresses the clergy and faithful of the Diocese of Rome during an assembly at the Basilica of St John Lateran, inviting the Church of Rome to walk alongside the people of God with "a pastoral ministry that is supportive, empathetic, discreet, non-judgmental, and able to welcome everyone.”

Read all

item.title: FAI turns down committee invite after garda 'guidance'
item.description: The Football Association of Ireland has turned down a request to attend a Joint Oireachtas Committee on sport hearing next week, regarding safeguarding issues, on the basis that it "risks prejudicing ongoing garda investigations"

item.title: Post-mortem examination taking place on child's remains
item.description: A post-mortem examination is being carried out on partial skeletal remains of a child recovered from wasteland in Donabate in Co Dublin.

item.title: 'Questions to answer' over Troubles legacy deal - victims
item.description: A new deal to address the legacy of Northern Ireland's past, agreed by the UK and Irish governments, will have a lot of questions to answer, victims have said.

item.title: Initial World Cup ticket presale draws more than 4.5 million applicants worldwide
item.description: More than 4.5 million people worldwide applied for FIFA's initial 2026 World Cup ticket presale. It was the first crack at FIFA's worldwide ticket lottery for the 48-team tournament.

item.title: Pope Leo to celebrate Mass at the parish of St Anne in the Vatican
item.description:
The Holy See Press Office announces that the Pope will go to the ancient church located within Vatican City State to celebrate the 25th Sunday in Ordinary Time. The place of worship, which dates back to the 16th century, has been entrusted to the pastoral care of the Order of St. Augustine since 1929.

item.title: Minimum pay rates to increase for contract cleaners
item.description: Minimum rates of pay for workers in the contract cleaning sector are to increase under a new Employment Regulation Order.

item.title: Taylor Swift returning to theatres alongside launch of next album
item.description: U.S. chain AMC Theatres announced Friday that Taylor Swift: The Official Release Party of a Showgirl will hit theatres October 3, which is also the release date for her next album, The Life of A Showgirl.

item.title: Over 300 events taking place in Dublin for Culture Night
item.description: More than 300 events are taking place in the capital to mark Dublin's 25th Culture Night.

item.title: Safeguards for veterans could hinder Troubles legacy deal
item.description: The detail of legal safeguards for British military veterans will have a huge bearing on how nationalist political parties and victims' organisations in Northern Ireland judge a new agreement on dealing with the legacy of Northern Ireland's Troubles, writes Vincent Kearney

item.description: More than 100 venues across Cork will open tonight as part of Culture Night events in the city.

item.description: A British couple have been reunited with their family in Qatar after their release from nearly eight months of detention in a Taliban facility in Afghanistan.

item.title: Israel expands attacks on Gaza City as Palestinians flee
item.description: Israel's military said it had expanded attacks on Gaza City as displaced Palestinians traumatised by the advance said they had no means to flee

item.title: High end luxury car models seized from M50 toll evaders
item.description: Mercedes Benz, BMW, Audi and Land Rover are some of the high end luxury car models that have been seized by the Dublin Sheriff from motorists to date this year who have racked up large bills concerning the non-payment on M50 tolls.

item.title: Kneecap to take legal action following Canadian ban
item.description: Irish rap trio Kneecap have said they are planning to take legal action against a member of the Canadian government for making statements about the band that they have branded "wholly untrue and deeply malicious".

item.title: New training program reaches out to under-represented, diverse filmmakers across Manitoba
item.description: A new — and free — film training program in Manitoba is being called revolutionary and the first of its kind in Canada.

item.title: Russian violation of Estonian airspace 'reckless' - NATO
item.description: NATO member Estonia's airspace was violated by three Russian military jets today, its government said, amid an increasingly tense atmosphere on the alliance's eastern flank.

item.title: Judge throws out Trump's $15B US lawsuit against the New York Times
item.description: A Florida federal judge on Friday tossed out a $15-billion US defamation lawsuit filed by U.S. President Donald Trump against the New York Times.

item.title: U.S. regulator sues Ticketmaster and Live Nation, alleging illegal resale tactics
item.description: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general sued Ticketmaster and its parent company on Thursday, saying they are forcing consumers to pay more to see live events through a variety of illegal tactics.

item.title: Paramilitary drone attack on mosque in Sudan kills at least 70 people, army says
item.description: A drone attack blamed on Sudan's paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces struck a mosque during prayers Friday, killing at least 70 worshippers in the North Darfur region, aid workers and the Sudanese army said.

item.title: Singer D4vd's shows cancelled amid investigation into body found in car
item.description: After the cancellation of a recent Seattle show, singer D4vd has appeared to cancel or suspend portions of his ongoing U.S. tour. The news comes shortly after a decomposed body was found inside an impounded Tesla in Los Angeles, identified as teenager Celeste Rivas — who went missing last year.

item.title: NATO, EU condemn Russia as Estonia says airspace was violated for 12 minutes
item.description: Estonia summoned a Russian diplomat to protest after three Russian fighter aircraft entered its airspace without permission Friday and stayed there for 12 minutes, an occurrence that the European Union said "further escalates tensions in the region."

item.title: Some athletes from Russia, Belarus can compete under neutral banner in Milan-Cortina Olympics
item.description: The International Olympic Committee will allow some individual athletes from Russia and Belarus to compete as neutral athletes at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics in February.

item.title: Chalk up a win for soft power as Donald Trump heads home from Britain happy
item.description: While Donald Trump's unusual second state visit to the U.K. this week appeared to be mostly about appealing to the U.S. president's ego, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer may have nudged Trump along on a couple of key points — notably Ukraine and Gaza.

item.title: Nepal: Church shares young people’s commitment to nation’s future
item.description:
Following recent unrest, calm has returned to Nepal as schools reopen and confidence grows in the transitional government, according to Fr. Silas Bogati, Apostolic Administrator of the Vicariate of Nepal.

item.title: SSE Airtricity to increase electricity prices by 9.5%
item.description: SSE Airtricity is to increase its standard variable electricity prices by 9.5% from next month, which will add around €150 annually onto a typical customer's bill.

item.title: RFK Jr.'s vaccine advisers change guidance around COVID shots, MMRV vaccines for young kids
item.description: The Friday vote takes a step back on recommending the COVID-19 shot — rather than recommending it outright for most adults as they have in the past, the panel voted that the vaccine should be available to everyone, and folks should make a personal decision about whether or not to get it alongside their doctor.

item.title: Govt and watchdog examining phone data revelations
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said the Government and the Data Protection Commissioner are examining revelations about the sale of Irish mobile phone location data.

item.title: Ignatius Maloyan: Armenian martyr soon to be saint
item.description:
Blessed Ignatius Maloyan, Archbishop of Mardin of the Armenian Catholics, is about to be proclaimed a Saint—an event marking a significant moment for the Armenian community and for the Catholic Church as a whole. The canonization Mass will take place in the Vatican on 19 October 2025.

item.title: ‘Tidal wave of emotion’ secures win for young Turkish writer in UN competition
item.description: Fifteen-year-old Reyyan Demiriz from Türkiye has been awarded first prize in a UN young writers’ competition which garnered a staggering 1.6 million entries from 65 different countries.
item.source:markdown: Fifteen-year-old Reyyan Demiriz from Türkiye has been awarded first prize in a UN young writers’ competition which garnered a staggering 1.6 million entries from 65 different countries.

item.title: UN backs Abbas video address after US visa refusal

item.title: Israeli air strikes in south Lebanon violate UN resolution
item.description: The UN peacekeeping mission in Lebanon (UNIFIL) on Friday called on the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) to refrain from further strikes and fully withdraw from Lebanese territory after Israeli strikes endangered peacekeepers and civilians overnight.

item.title: UN Security Council rejects bid to continue Iran sanctions relief
item.description: A proposal to continue sanctions relief for Iran under the 2015 nuclear deal was rejected in the UN Security Council on Friday in a vote that revealed deep divisions over the so-called “snapback” process.

item.title: Sudan crisis: Surge in summary executions by all warring parties
item.description: At least 75 people have been killed, according to news reports, in a drone strike on a mosque during morning prayers in El Fasher city, in the west of the war-torn country.

item.title: UNICEF aid trucks robbed at gunpoint in Gaza City
item.description: Humanitarian aid in Gaza must be protected, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) said on Friday, following the theft of therapeutic food critical for saving thousands of young lives from malnutrition as famine spreads.

item.title: Afghanistan quake: Rescuers dodge dangers, women and girls face disaster, warns UN
item.description: Women and girls still reeling from Afghanistan's deadly earthquake face even greater suffering rebuilding their lives and livelihoods – with little help to hand, gender equality agency UN Women said on Friday.

item.title: Gazans flee ‘death and devastation’ with no transportation or means of shelter
item.description: In the face of escalating Israeli military operations, thousands of Palestinian families continue to flee the northern Gaza Strip amid dire humanitarian conditions and transportation shortages.

item.description:
Blessed Ignatius Maloyan, Archbishop of Mardin of the Armenian Catholics, is about to be proclaimed a Saint—an event marking a significant moment for the Armenian community and for the Catholic Church as a whole. The canonization Mass will take place in the Vatican on 19 October 2025.

item.title: Guardians of Creation: Children bring faith to life caring for our planet
item.description:
In Tucumán, Argentina, children are living their faith as Guardians of Creation, planting trees, mentoring peers, and learning to care for our planet through the Laudato Si’ initiative.”

item.title: What is Antifa and can the U.S. declare it a terrorist group?
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump says he wants to declare Antifa a major terrorist organization. But it's not clear whether he can even do that because though Antifa — short for anti-fascist — is a movement that exists around the world, it is not a single group.

item.title: Papua New Guinea awaits its first Saint: The story of Peter To Rot
item.description:
Catholics in Papua New Guinea feel they are living a historic moment. This October, the Catholic Church will canonize Blessed Peter To Rot, making him the nation’s first saint. The postulator for his cause sheds light on the saint and his story.

item.description: The European Union has proposed to bring forward a ban on Russian gas imports as part of a new package of sanctions aimed at sapping Moscow's war chest, and pleasing US President Donald Trump.

item.title: Pope Leo: God gave families the perfect model, the Holy Family
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV invites families to follow the example of the Holy Family, the 'perfect model' God offers us, and calls on them to rediscover the faith of their grandparents and parents which, through Jesus, brings true joy, in his remarks to participants in the Jubilee Meeting organized by the Latin American and Caribbean Episcopal Council (CELAM) on the future of the family.

item.description: The Low Pay Commission is expected to recommend to the Government an increase of 5% to the National Minimum Wage.

item.description: A man in his 20s has died after a collision between a car and a van on the Mayo/Galway border this morning.

item.title: Sheridan fails to get Carlow County Council's nomination
item.description: Presidential hopeful Gareth Sheridan has failed to get a nomination from Carlow County Council.

item.title: Dominican sisters in Zimbabwe train young people in health sector
item.description:
For over 60 years, the Dominican Sisters in Zimbabwe have run St. Theresa Hospital in Chirimanzu, making a profound impact on the lives of young people by training them to become skilled primary care nurses and registered general nurses. Their legacy of compassion, education, and healthcare continues to shape the future of nursing in Zimbabwe.

item.title: Ukraine: Sisters of Blessed Honorat bind wounds of human suffering
item.description:
Founded to help people in need, the Little Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary are staying beside the people of Ukraine during the war, listening, comforting, and feeding those affected by the violence. “It does not matter to me whether I die in Poland or Ukraine, because my sisters and my community are there,” said Mother Judyta Kowalska, Superior General.

item.description: Pakistan's defence minister has said that his nation's nuclear program "will be made available" to Saudi Arabia if needed under the countries' new defence pact.

item.description:

item.description: A Derry musician who lost his son in a road traffic collision has created a tribute album to honour children and young people who have died on Irish and Northern Irish roads.

item.description: A member of Long Lake #58 First Nation in northern Ontario is being honoured in a display that's more than 1,200 kilometres away. item.title: DRC: Deadly armed groups, militias, and thieves target Church institutions in Ituri
item.description:
In the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), the Church is once again reeling from yet another attack. During the night of 15 September and 16 September, assailants armed with hammers, knives, crowbars, and all manner of tools stormed a preparatory training school near the Bishop’s residence in the Mudzipela neighbourhood of the Shari community in Bunia, the Provincial city of Ituri Province.

item.title: Aid driver kills 2 Israeli military personnel at Jordan border crossing, authorities say
item.description: A driver bringing humanitarian aid from Jordan for Gaza opened fire and killed two Israeli military personnel at the Allenby Crossing into the West Bank on Thursday before being killed by security forces, authorities from both nations said.

item.title: Pope Leo sees role as one of building bridges, avoiding polarization
item.description:
A new biography of Pope Leo, “Leo XIV: Citizen of the World, Missionary of the 21st Century,” contains the full text of the interview granted by the Holy Father to Elise Ann Allen, covering a wide range of topics, including the tragedy of Gaza, the Church’s policy on China, the role of women, the Church’s welcome of those who identify as LGBTQ+, the clerical abuse crisis, the financial situation of the Holy See, artificial intelligence, and fake news.

item.title: Irish choreographer cuts ties with theatre over Gaza

item.title: 'Distinct possibility' EU will suspend Israel trade deal
item.description: The Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Harris has said he believes it is a "distinct possibility" that the European Union will suspend parts of a cooperation deal with Israel that allows for reduced tariffs on goods coming from the country.

item.title: Supreme Court asked to hear Conor McGregor appeal

item.title: Foster family 'devastated' by boy's disappearance

item.title: Security Council: US votes against resolution on Gaza ceasefire
item.description: The United States once again vetoed a UN resolution demanding an immediate, unconditional and permanent ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, following a vote in the Security Council on Thursday.

item.title: Sudan: UN relief chief welcomes progress towards three-month truce
item.description: The UN relief chief Tom Fletcher has highlighted recent diplomatic progress made towards a three-month pause to the brutal fighting in Sudan between rival militaries.

item.title: GAZA LIVE: US vetoes UN Security Council resolution demanding unrestricted flow of aid
item.description: The United States vetoed a draft resolution in the Security Council on Thursday put forward by its 10 non-permanent members demanding an immediate, unconditional and permanent ceasefire in Gaza – and the immediate release of all hostages. Against the backdrop of rising famine it also demanded the lifting of Israeli restrictions on aid, calling on the occupying power to ensure safe and unhindered distribution to all in need. News app users can follow our live meetings coverage by going here.

item.title: Gaza City lifelines collapsing, UN aid agency warns
item.description: The last remaining lifelines for civilians in Gaza City are collapsing as Israel ramps up military operations, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said on Thursday.

item.title: Fragile progress in Syria, at risk from exclusion and foreign interference, UN warns
item.description: Syria’s tentative steps towards recovery could quickly unravel without inclusive politics, sustained aid and respect for national sovereignty, top UN officials cautioned the Security Council on Thursday.

item.title: ‘No end’ expected to floods and storms as global heating continues
item.description: The world’s water resources face growing pressure from climate change while emergencies involving the life-giving resource are increasingly impacting lives and livelihoods, the UN World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said on Thursday.
item.source:markdown: The world’s water resources face growing pressure from climate change while emergencies involving the life-giving resource are increasingly impacting lives and livelihoods, the UN World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said on Thursday.

item.title: UN presses ahead with mission for a better world despite global headwinds
item.description: During a year of escalating global turmoil – from widening wars and economic hardship to the relentless advance of the climate crisis – the United Nations has held its ground, working to promote peace, drive sustainable development, and ease human suffering.

item.title: Guterres pushes leaders to ‘turn the tide’ on global crises during high-stakes UNGA week
item.description: Secretary-General António Guterres has issued a stark call to world leaders on the eve of the United Nations General Assembly’s high-level week, warning that a “global crisis” of war, climate change, inequality and technological risk demands urgent, coordinated action.

item.description: World leaders are converging on United Nations Headquarters along the East River in Manhattan for what is shaping up to be one of the most consequential annual gatherings in recent memory.

item.title: UN80 Initiative: New report charts proposals for change across UN structures and programmes

item.title: Polish missile likely damaged house during incursion

item.description: The Ukrainian conflict has recorded the highest confirmed death and injury toll from cluster munitions for the third year running, UN-backed researchers said on Monday.

item.title: MI5 admits it unlawfully obtained journalist's data twice
item.description: The British intelligence service, MI5, has admitted that it unlawfully obtained the data of journalist Vincent Kearney on two occasions.

item.title: MI5 admits it unlawfully obtained journalist's data twice
item.description: The British intelligence service, MI5, has admitted that it unlawfully obtained the data of journalist Vincent Kearney on two occasions.

item.title: Arab, Islamic states meet in Qatar after Israeli strike
item.description:
Arab and Islamic nations convene an emergency meeting in Qatar following Israel’s airstrike last week targeting Hamas leaders in Doha.

Read all

item.title: Luxembourg's regulator to be quizzed on Israel decision
item.description: Luxembourg's financial regulator is going to be questioned by politicians tomorrow following its decision to approve paperwork to allow Israel raise money in the EU.

item.title: As it happened: Councils vote on Áras hopefuls
item.description: As local authorities around the country meet to hear from potential candidates in the upcoming Presidential Election, follow all of the latest developments live.

item.title: US and China reach framework deal on TikTok
item.description: The US and China have reached a framework agreement to switch short-video app TikTok to US-controlled ownership, top US officials said today, with President Donald Trump set to speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Friday.

item.title: Rising to the challenge: Zimbabwe’s young religious called to be Pilgrims of Hope
item.description:
Young temporarily professed religious sisters, brothers, and priests have been called to experience and embody hope through the charism of their congregations. These sentiments were expressed by organisers of a recent national workshop for young male and female religious persons held over the weekend, in Chinhoyi, Zimbabwe. The gathering encouraged participants to live lives marked by transparency, accountability, and moral integrity.

Read all

item.title: Six councils decline to nominate presidential candidate
item.description: Six local authorities made the decision not to nominate a candidate in the Presidential Election.

item.title: Religious sisters work for an indigenous Church with an Amazonian face
item.description:
In the heart of the jungle in Cuzco, Peru, Sr. Giovanna Llerena Alfaro, a Dominican Missionary of the Rosary, walks alongside the Indigenous communities of Bajo Urubamba, promoting an Indigenous Church and a form of evangelization that arises from contemplation.

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo XIV appoints new Apostolic Nuncio to Spain and Andorra
item.description:
Archbishop Piero Pioppo is appointed the new Apostolic Nuncio to Spain and the Principality of Andorra.

Read all

item.title: Calls for reform after Catholic on pilgrimage killed in Pakistan
item.description:
With sorrow and shock over the recent murder of a 42-year-old man shot dead while on pilgrimage in the Archdiocese of Lahore, leading experts in Pakistan are calling for serious and effective social reforms, especially in education, to combat the phenomenon.

Read all

item.title: From Gaza to Europe via jet ski: A Palestinian man's daring escape from the war
item.description: It took more than a year, several thousand dollars, ingenuity, setbacks and a jet ski: this is how Muhammad Abu Dakha, a 31-year-old Palestinian, managed to escape from Gaza to reach Europe.

item.title: Australia to suffer more extreme climate events - report
item.description: Australia will suffer more frequent and extreme climate events, often happening simultaneously, which will strain industry, services and infrastructure, a government report has said, ahead of the announcement of a new emissions target.

item.title: Spain threaten Eurovision boycott if Israel participate
item.description: Spain should boycott next year's Eurovision Song Contest if Israel takes part, Spanish Culture Minister Ernest Urtasun has said, joining Ireland and other European nations threatening to pull out of the event.

item.title: Spain threatens Eurovision boycott if Israel participates
item.description: Spain should boycott next year's Eurovision Song Contest if Israel takes part, Spanish Culture Minister Ernest Urtasun has said, joining Ireland and other European nations threatening to pull out of the event.

item.title: German man refused interview over McCann disappearance
item.description: British police investigating the disappearance of Madeleine McCann, a three-year-old British girl who vanished in Portugal in 2007, said a 49-year-old German man remained a suspect but had refused to be interviewed.

item.title: German man refused interview over McCann disappearance
item.description: British police investigating the disappearance of Madeleine McCann, a three-year-old British girl who vanished in Portugal in 2007, said a 49-year-old German man remained a suspect but had refused to be interviewed.

item.title: Pope to Augustinians: Keep love at the centre of religious life
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV meets with Augustinians at the conclusion of their General Chapter and invites them to place love at the centre of their religious life.

Read all

item.title: Lewis Capaldi announces three huge Irish gigs for 2026
item.description: Lewis Capaldi has said it is "surreal" to be announcing his biggest ever tour as he confirmed a series of huge gigs in Ireland and the UK for next summer.

item.title: Aid flotilla sets sail for Gaza from Tunisia after delays
item.description: A flotilla bound for Gaza carrying aid and pro-Palestinian activists has set sail from Tunisia after repeated delays, aiming to break Israel's blockade and establish a humanitarian corridor to the Palestinian territory.

item.title: Beninese Bishop: Jihadist attacks aim at preventing Church's activity
item.description:
Following a recent attack by jihadists, the Bishop of N'Dali, Benin, Martin Adjou Moumouni, explains that the community is concerned about further violence as the militants "have also made it clear that they want to prevent the Church from continuing its pastoral activities.”

Read all

item.title: Family suing coroner, Island Health after body of First Nations man returned without brain
item.description: Two years after the death of her father, Amanda Large received news that brought added grief and unanswered questions: her father’s brain, which had been removed during an autopsy, had never been returned to them. It's not the first time an Indigenous person's body parts have been misplaced.

item.title: Man due in court after death of pensioner in Tipperary
item.description: A man is due to appear in court in Nenagh in connection with the investigation into the death of a man in his 80s in Tipperary Town on Friday night.

item.title: Man charged at Nenagh court over burglary and assault
item.description: A 31-year-old man has appeared at Nenagh District Court charged in connection with an incident in Tipperary town on Friday night.

item.title: O'Brien 'hoping' for daa and Kenny Jacobs agreement
item.description: Minister for Transport Darragh O'Brien said he is "hoping" for an agreement between the board of Dublin Airport Authority (daa) and its chief executive Kenny Jacobs.

item.title: Vancouver Island municipality's move to consider logging upsets collaboration efforts, says First Nation
item.description: First Nations in the North Cowichan region in Vancouver Island B.C. say a motion by the Municipality of North Cowichan has undermined collaborative efforts on the future of logging in the region's forest reserve.

item.title: 26% of Irish adults don't have retirement plan in place
item.description: New research shows there has been in an increase in the number of Irish adults who do not have a retirement plan in place.

item.title: Rubio promises 'unwavering support' for Israel in Gaza
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio has vowed that Washington would provide "unwavering support" to Israel in achieving its goals in Gaza as he called for the eradication of Hamas.

item.title: Watch: Sabina Higgins looks forward to life after Áras
item.description: Sabina Higgins, the wife of President Michael D Higgins, has said she is "so looking forward" to returning home to Co Galway when his term ends.

item.title: DNA found at Kirk murder scene matched to suspect - FBI
item.description: DNA found at the scene of the murder of US conservative influencer Charlie Kirk has been matched to suspect Tyler Robinson, FBI director Kash Patel has said.

item.title: McGregor withdraws bid to run in Presidential Election
item.description: Former MMA fighter Conor McGregor has announced he is withdrawing from the Presidential Election race.

item.title: Rain warning for Clare, Cork, Kerry, Limerick & Galway
item.description: A Status Yellow rain warning has been issued for five counties in the west and south.

item.title: PBP-Solidarity gather ahead of new Dáil term
item.description: Members of People Before Profit-Solidarity have gathered in Dublin this morning to discuss their political priorities for the new Dáil term, which begins on Wednesday.

item.title: Former soldier goes on trial over Bloody Sunday murders
item.description: A former British soldier has gone on trial charged with murdering two men on Bloody Sunday in Co Derry in 1972.

item.title: Bloody Sunday shootings 'unjustified', soldier trial told
item.description: The shooting of civilians on Bloody Sunday by a former paratrooper and his platoon mates were "unjustified", "unnecessary" and "gratuitous", the veteran's murder trial has heard

item.title: This man needs HIV prevention drugs. The Kenyan clinics providing them will soon lose U.S. funding
item.description: Ibrahim Lwingi lost many family members to HIV/AIDS and says he likely would've been next without prevention meds from Nairobi clinics operated by the University of Manitoba since the 1980s. The program is set to lose U.S. funding by the end of the month, and both staff and patients are worried about what's next.

item.title: Harris seeks clarity from Europe on Israeli sanctions
item.description: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Harris has initiated a coordinated diplomatic effort to gain clarity from the European Commission about how quickly it will move to sanction Israel over its actions in Gaza and the West Bank.

item.title: Joshua Odjick fans make long journey to see Kitigan Zibi actor on the big screen
item.description: Members of the Maniwaki Native Friendship Centre made a two-hour journey to Gatineau, Que., for the opening night screening of The Long Walk — a Stephen King adaptation starring Kitigan Zibi actor Joshua Odjick.

item.title: Harris seeks clarity from Europe on Israeli sanctions
item.description: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Harris has initiated a coordinated diplomatic effort to gain clarity from the European Commission about how quickly it will move to sanction Israel over its actions in Gaza and the West Bank.

item.title: Adolescence star becomes youngest ever male Emmy winner
item.description: Adolescence star Owen Cooper has become the youngest male actor to win a Primetime Emmy, taking Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Limited or Anthology Series or Movie at age 15 for the Netflix drama.
